abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Karnataka Power Project in India. The
            principal project objectives were to alleviate power
            shortage in the state of Karnataka and the southern region
            by exploiting hydro resources, to provide efficient
            transmission capacity, and to effect institutional,
            operational and financial improvements in the two power
            utilities of the state. The performance of the Bank in
            respect of project preparation and appraisal cannot be
            considered satisfactory. Borrower’s performance was not
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned from the project were:
            (i) many of the project components preparation had not been
            sufficiently advanced to warrant approval of a loan; (ii)
            project management capabilities should have been more
            rigorously assessed and the project management organization
            designed accordingly; and (iii) measures need to be
            introduced before loan approval to create an appropriate
            regulatory environment to ensure the creditworthiness of the
            power sector entities and which would prevent the government
            from disallowing tariff increases for political reasons.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Karnataka Power Project aims to:
            (i) assist in meeting electricity demand in the State of
            Karnataka and the Southern Region of India and to (ii)
            effect institutional, operational and financial improvements
            in relation to both Karnataka Power Corporation (KPC) and
            Karnataka Electricity Board (KEB).  The project seeks to
            accomplish this through (a) the addition of 270 MW of hydro
            capacity on the Kalinadi River; (b) rehabilitation of the
            Sharavathi Power Station; and (c) reinforcement of the
            State's transmission system. In addition, the project
            intends to provide consulting services, computer hardware,
            software and training.  There are no extraordinary technical
            risks associated with the project.  Geological
            investigations have confirmed generally good rock formation
            in the area of the hydro schemes.  KPC and KEB have staff
            familiar with works similar to those included in the
            proposed project and consulting support will be provided in
            those areas in which the beneficiaries lack experience.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Karnataka Power Project aims to:
            (i) assist in meeting electricity demand in the State of
            Karnataka and the Southern Region of India and to (ii)
            effect institutional, operational and financial improvements
            in relation to both Karnataka Power Corporation (KPC) and
            Karnataka Electricity Board (KEB).  The project seeks to
            accomplish this through (a) the addition of 270 MW of hydro
            capacity on the Kalinadi River; (b) rehabilitation of the
            Sharavathi Power Station; and (c) reinforcement of the
            State's transmission system. In addition, the project
            intends to provide consulting services, computer hardware,
            software and training.  There are no extraordinary technical
            risks associated with the project.  Geological
            investigations have confirmed generally good rock formation
            in the area of the hydro schemes.  KPC and KEB have staff
            familiar with works similar to those included in the
            proposed project and consulting support will be provided in
            those areas in which the beneficiaries lack experience.
